description.plain:
Arguably the greatest songwriter of the latter half of the 20th century, Robinson’s timeless creations for Motown, both for his own group and for other artists, provided the ultimate example of what a pop song can be.  From The Beatles to Bob Dylan, the rest of the 60s followed in his wake

As if that wasn’t enough, he created a whole new genre in the mid-70s with “quiet storm”, a radio format named after one of his songs.  He continues writing and performing today.

songs.full_title: Cruisin' by Smokey Robinson
songs.title: Cruisin’

description.plain:
“Cruisin'” became a big pop hit for Smokey Robinson, peaking at #4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #4 on Billboard’s R&B Singles chart in February 1980.

Guitarist Marv Tarplin had written the music five years before Robinson came up with lyrics he was finally satisfied with. After hearing The Rascals “Groovin'”, he considered making that the main concept of the song, but later came up with “Cruisin'” instead and felt it matched the song’s ‘sensual’ sound better.

songs.full_title: Being with You by Smokey Robinson
songs.title: Being with You

description.plain:
Who’d have thought a song that repeats the words “I Don’t Care” over and over would become a huge hit? “Being With You” was the title track of Smokey Robinson’s 1981 album. Robinson originally wrote this song for Kim Carnes, but when Carnes' producer George Tobin informed Robinson he no longer worked with her, Tobin convinved Robinson to keep it for himself.

“Being With You” topped the pop charts in the UK and New Zealand. It peaked at #2 in the US, kept from the top spot by Sheena Easton’s “Morning Train (9 to 5)”, then Kim Carnes' “Bette Davis Eyes”. However, it did top the R&B Singles chart for five weeks.

Robinson’s wife Claudette is one of the background vocalists heard on the track, alongside Robert “Sad Eyes” John.

songs.title: Just to See Her

description.plain:
Just to See Her peaked at #8 on the Billboard Hot 100, #2 on Billboard’s R&B Singles chart and topped Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart for a week in May of 1987.

The song also earned Smokey Robinson a Grammy Award for “Best Male R&B Vocal Performance”, the first in his career.

songs.lyrics:
You got to do like I do, oh, like I do
When we're far apart and your lonesome heart
Makes your eyes wander to somebody new
You might want them so much, you can look but, oh, don't touch

You got to do like I do, recognize desire as a physical need
That you can rise above, oh, like I do
Don't love the one you're with? Search 'til you get with the one you love
Oh, like I do, you got to do like I do

When you're out with your friends and the coupling off begins
And the heavy rappers start to hit on you
If the question is romance, let the answer be, "No chance"
Do like I do, let it in one ear, right past your smile out of the other

Oh, like I do, don't let another lost soul
Talk you into going undercover, do like I do

I know gossip would take a love so good
And spread the proof of one of us is playing, they been saying
Oh, don't give me that he said, that she said that they said, that we said
On it goes

How the stories starts and stops, nobody knows
But I got my baby
Check them so they know that they can go 'til it freezes over
Oh, like I do

Even if they try 'til the fourth of July
Comes in our door, yeah
They never gonna break us up
If you do like I do

Like I do, oh
Like I do, oh
You got to do like I do
Do like I do
